title: Who was the MVP of the 2022 Chicago Cubs?
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(ggrepel)

playersbatting <- read_csv("chicagocubs.csv")
chicagofielding<- read_csv("chicagocubsfielding.csv")

playersbatting %>%
  filter(PA>25)%>%
mutate(
  SOperPA= SO/PA,
  HperPA= H/PA) -> SOandH

SOandH %>% filter(Name== "Nico Hoerner") -> nico

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=SOandH, 
    aes(x=SOperPA, y=HperPA, size=PA), 
    color="grey", 
    alpha=.5) + 
  geom_point(
    data=nico, 
    aes(x=SOperPA, y=HperPA, size=PA), 
    color="#CC3433")+
  geom_vline(xintercept = 0.2358691) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0.1997675) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=nico, 
    aes(x=SOperPA, y=HperPA, label=Name)
  )+
  labs(x="Strikeouts per Plate Appearance", y= "Hits per Plate Appearance", title="Who do the Cubs want up in the bottom of the 9th?", subtitle="Nico Hoerner was the MVP at the plate leading the team with the highest batting average.", caption="Source: Sports Reference | By Lauren Anderson")  + theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=12), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    )





Nico Hoerner thrived at the plate in his first year in a regular starting position. He starting 135 games this season, and stepped up to the plate 481 times, only behind Ian Happ. Hoerner also posted the highest batting average on the team in 2022.
He didn’t just have a MVP year at home plate, but on the bases as well.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(ggrepel)

playersbatting <- read_csv("chicagocubs.csv")
chicagofielding<- read_csv("chicagocubsfielding.csv")

stealing<- playersbatting %>%
  filter(SB>5, CS>1)%>%
  select(Name, SB, CS)%>%
  mutate(stling= CS/SB)%>%
  arrange((stling))%>%
  ungroup()%>%
  top_n(10)

stealing <- stealing%>% mutate(Name=gsub("\\*", "", Name)) %>% mutate(Name=gsub("\\#", "", Name))

stealing %>% 
  gt() %>% 
  cols_label(
    stling = "Failed Stealing Percentage",
    SB= "Stolen Base",
    CS= "Caught Stealing"
  ) %>%
  tab_header(
    title = "Nico Hoerner quick flashy on the bases in 2022",
    subtitle = "He pushed the limits this season on the bases leading the team with the most successful stolen bases "
  )%>%tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Lauren Anderson |  **Source:** Sports Reference")
  ) %>%
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
   ) %>%
  opt_row_striping() %>% 
  opt_table_lines("none") %>%
    fmt_percent(
    columns = c(stling),
    decimals = 1
  ) %>%
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#CC3433"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Name == "Nico Hoerner")
  )

Manager David Ross has made it clear in the media that he wants his players pushing the limits and being aggressive with their base running.
Again, Nico Hoerner was the greatest representation of those words this season, he finished on top of the roster for the Cubs.
So… he gets on base, and runs fast while he is there, but, what about on the other side of the game?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(ggrepel)

playersbatting <- read_csv("chicagocubs.csv")
chicagofielding<- read_csv("chicagocubsfielding.csv")

chicagofielding %>% 
  group_by(Name) %>% 
  filter(Inn>200)%>%
  summarise(
    SeasonErrors= sum(E),
    SeasonDoublePlay= sum(DP))-> errors

errors%>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols=starts_with("Season"),
    names_to = "Type",
    values_to = "Plays")-> errorswide
  
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=errorswide, 
    aes(x=reorder(Name, Plays), weight=Plays, fill=Type)) + scale_fill_manual(values = c("#CC3433","#0E3386"))+
  coord_flip()+
  labs(
    x="Players", 
    y="Total Number of Errors and Double Players", 
    title="Can the MVP play defense?", 
    subtitle="Although it could also be sloppy Nico Hoerner is flashy with a glove.", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | By Lauren Anderson"
    )





As the starting shortstop Hoerner has opportunities to show off his glove in big plays more then others, it is what he does with those chances that makes him such a great player.
Yes, Javy Baez, at the time, might have seemed to be impossible to replace in the eyes of Cubs fans, but truly, they replaced him and Hoerner had a much better season then Baez did in Detroit. With the season he had Nico Hoerner deserves to be labeled the MVP of the 2022 Chicago Cubs.
